comments.commentBody: I have a friend who was a school superintendent in a small city in the Bay Area with a large minority population. When we discussed parental participation with them, he said that he wanted parents to be at home for the children, but he would see that they get a good education. He said that was tailored to the population that he was dealing with, and that he might have accepted more participation if his schools were in other communities, although I suspect that he would say that parents being available for their children would be important everywhere.

When I buy an equity, it has already been taxed, and any dividends are actually taxed twice. Dividends are paid after the company has paid the corporate taxes, and distributed some the remaining profit to the stock holders.
When those dividends are paid to the stock holder, they are taxed again.

Many people like me, get our retirement income from investing in stock and bonds, so chances are, our total tax bill is equal or even greater than yours by percentage of income. In case you do not know, 85% of our Social Security is taxed if we have a total income over $65,000 or so.

"We" are not "giving"huge sums to the financial industry, we are paying to be in the market, but are paying more than we should. if you mean by "We" it is not the public that is paying, it is the investors.

It's  amazing to me that the high flying frat boys of the flunkie finance industry still depend on the material basis of production like laying cable under the Hudson River.  The technology is more advanced, yes, but it is still about transforming nature into something valuable through labor power for our purposes.   Tax financial transactions and use the funds to build the tunnel Christie wouldn't.

From the point of view of rich investors, the super fast traders may not appear such a bad thing. That is insofar as richer investors, and mutual funds too, do not rely so much on short-term trading.
The effect of the fast trading, and other perceived unfairness, is to deter any easy profit-making attempted by the smallest traders, who often have to take a very long time to do even one trade. It becomes almost impossible, to make profits anyway, according to simply technical analysis by itself, in the short term. That is however not strictly as true as they claim. In any case, making profits in the short term depends upon having the very best technical analysis technique(s), and that is simply unavailable at most any reasonable price.

Andrew:

If you live in Port Washington, you should know that the overruns on immense tunnel and bridge projects are "normally" huge. Christie's primary argument against approving it was that NJ taxpayers would be largely stuck with any overrun, because the Feds explicitly washed their hands of any related obligations to cover them; and this state already is dealing with higher-than-average unemployment, huge debt and very substantial education, Medicaid, public sector union retirement and other infrastructure obligations.

The up-side arguments you make have been made by many. So long as we're held harmless from the labor-and-cumshaw-related predations that these boondoggles inevitably attract in the Northeast and Mid-Atlantic, it'd be a good deal. If we're not, on balance, we can't afford the risk.

In America, we never spoke of "allowing" business activities, as if activity were a chattel of the state, to be allowed or not depending on government perception of how well its interests are served. People, with inherent rights, undertake activity for whatever non-criminal purpose they see fit, and it's government's legitimate role merely to regulate to minimize proven predation.

Regulators often are "helpless" because to prohibit activity or to mandate its nature or performance, government must pass a law that is constitutional -- you don't like an activity, get a law passed. Business has no requirement otherwise to justify itself as contributive to "society as a whole".

John, I don't quite follow your alluding to Christina Hendricks, as "Twin Peaks" ran only for two seasons in the early 90's?

Howie

You do not have to pay that 2% if you manage your own account, unless it is a 401K, or even a traditional defined benefit retirement account But you are paying for expertise, that most of you do not have, and do not have an understanding of how to invest well anyway.

The management money these managers take out, is not tax free. Your IRA and 401K money is pre tax money out of your paycheck, but you pay income tax on it when you withdraw it.

These management funds do get a lower tax rate due to something called carry forward income, which needs to be corrected, but it is not "TAX FREE."

Years ago, Krugman wrote in some of his columns that the financial industry had become much too big a part of our economy, as much as twice as big as needed to fulfill its financing, liquidity, and risk-moderating functions for a productive modern economy. I'm glad he's using the popularity of "Flash Boys" to come back to the subject. Perhaps the need to cut down excessive financial speculation will finally get some leverage among policy makers.

The idea of a very low % tax on trades mentioned in a number of comments was also mentioned by Krugman and others years ago. Such a tax would be easily borne by people and institutions who buy, hold, and sell securities over long periods for productive economic purposes. But it would hit high-frequency traders and other speculators hard while generating huge tax receipts that could go for productive public purposes. It would be an economic experiment worth trying--to see if reducing the financial industry's share of GDP hurts the greater economy, helps it, or has a neutral effect.

"playing small investors for suckers". So true, but unfortunately we're all suckers in this game. Most of us need to invest retirement savings in mutual funds because there really is no alternative. Yet these financial wizards are skimming a big fraction of the gains off the top to keep for themselves (and I don't mean just the mutual fund admin fees). Without reasonable government regulation, there is not much we can do.

I don't think the concerns about artificially changing one's mood are as rare as you imply. I've gone through undeniable bouts of depression and have seriously considered in these times whether chemically altering the state of my brain is the answer, or whether there's something I need to work through with full clarity, and thus whether the chemicals will only delay or skewer that process. This is also a theme in Douglas Coupland's fiction -- in his short story "Life After God" (from the collection of the same name), the main character comes to the conclusion that antidepressants do indeed cut the lowest lows out of his life, but at the price of the highest highs. Fiction or no, this story is an example that these concerns are part of our cultural discourse.

I think the author of this piece fleshes out his idea of happiness beyond just the opposite of depression and anxiety, and your definition of happiness as "fully engaging / being engaged by the world in a low-anxiety way" isn't really at odds with it.

I do like your comments about permanent content and continually recreating the self. The ability to adapt does seem like part of the answer here.
Too late, already sold.

Capitalism at work, it seems; unrestricted, unregulated (regulators looking the other way?), parasitic, leeches at work in the name of greed. Not a good omen. Our politicians, by accepting bribes to benefit their masters, may need an act of contrition and change their ways, otherwise we are doomed. We would hate to see a sign "democracy for sale" in the not too distant future.

Yes the transactions are not taxed, but any profits are. So taxing the transaction will cost the investor more. If it is part of a retirement account, you pay ordinary income on any withdrawals. If it is a buy for an investment account, you pay ordinary taxes on any gains if you hold the equity less than a year, and capital gains if it is over a year when you sell it. You pay tax on any dividends in an equity account. We are not getting away tax free.

The only thing more wasteful than our financial sector in terms of return on investment is gambling (of which it is a subset) and war--especially our recent war based on lies supposed to get control of another country's resources and which failed on all counts. Sadly, all three subvert, corrupt, and pervert our democracy.
It's a fairy tale to believe such could happen. Washing no longer makes it so.

We also could increase the number of capital gains tax brackets.

Start by taxing capital gains earned on assets held for less than 24 hours at 90%.

Capital gains on assets held for less than seven days would be taxed at 80%.

On the other end, capital gains on assets held for longer than 25 years would be taxed at just five percent.

Special categories would be set up for entrepreneurs who actually create something tangible, like buying a rundown house and refurbishing it. So assets where the buyer invests at least 25% of the purchase price to improve it would be taxed at, say 20%.

Money is power and it well past time to limit the power of the richest.

Let there be an ever increasing wealth tax starting at $5 million.

Limit a person's net worth to $50 million. Anyone that was able to accumulate $50 million achieved it by unjust enrichment.

Use the proceeds to:
- lower the national debt
- create jobs in education, health care and infrastructure projects
- lower the tax burden of those trying to make their first million.

If someone with a net worth of $50 million wants power, let them go into public service or run for office.

You are so right.  Has anybody else noticed that two recent studies (one in Ohio and one in Italy) have pointed out the correlation between fracking and earthquakes?

Our side, the opposition of the fossil fuel industry, will not succeed through fighting in the street. We have to understand that the fight will be won or lost in the polling booth by people making careful choices when they vote.

No "push" is going to happen until the fossil fuel industry are dislodged from the catbird seat in American and international politics.

But political warfare is fought with money, which the fossil fuel industry and their political lackeys have in abundance, or street protest, which is met with police in body armor and armed with heavy weaponry who work for fossil fuel money and protect policy makers in the pocket of planet killers.

Humanity is in the midst of a war for planet Earth, and humanity is losing.
Thank you for posting this wonderfully encouraging feedback.
Thank you for having the courage to confront those without shame who want their threats to be met with silence. Thank you for your truth. Thank you for your inner strength.

Your father's company paid him to develop the building system, so they own it. The system was no more his than the cabinets in your kitchen belong to the carpenter who made them. What is so difficult to understand about this?

Krista,

Of course that's occurred to me. In fact, I even acknowledged it with my questioning. Is it the only patent ever issued to have an unlimited duration? Obviously, the answer is no, as all patents have a limited lifetime. However, whether or not a company decides to produce the invention protected by the patent, it will still be public knowledge. In the vast majority of cases, these patents do not cover a period greater than the two decades following filing (and none are unlimited), and therefore, there will come a time when anyone, RoughAcres' father included, may freely make the invention described therein. That time may even be now.

The realm of finance is very different from the realm of intellectual property covered by patents, because patents are intended to, and do, have a limited lifetime. The knowledge the public gains from the publishing of patents lasts as long as we maintain a copy of the patent, the right of the patent holder to enforce the patent is not extended ad infinitum. Your complaints about the finance industry, which are valid and I agree with, do not translate to the patent system with its clearly defined tradeoff of limited monopoly for substantive public disclosure.

There are problems with the patent system, but this isn't one of them.

Nathan an Expat, check out David Mamet's play 'The Water Engine', which is based on an urban legend concerning just such a device. While you're at it, check out the recent IFC parody series, 'The Spoils of Babylon', in which the McGuffin is a similar invention that the villainess would go to great lengths to suppress. That story's been kicking around quite awhile.

My father worked for a large midwest corporation as a research chemist - and invented a highly sustainable modular building system which was tested under both arctic and desert conditions.

Ultimately, the corporation decided to go a different direction with its products, and abandoned their work in this area. My father - who had been forced to sign over his patent to them - sought to buy it back.

They refused.

This has always enraged me; HIS creative work became THEIRS... even though they didn't want it. And a highly efficient, inexpensive modular building system - which could have had a multitude of uses throughout the world - will never be put into production.

G. Love, I thank you as I earlier thanked Adler from Vermont for raising the fundamental questions that these and countless other researchers whose original articles and books I read refuse to face.

My basic example of this failure arises when I read epidemiological studies in which the researchers compare what they call "races" meaning in American research a black "race" and a white "race".

An added example comes from reading and writing a 496 word review of "Creating A New Racial Order-How Immigration, Multiracialism, Genomics, and the Young Can Remake Race in America". These authors admit that they cannot even define "race", their basic variable.

Sure, researchers cannot only be concerned with individuals, but with groups so ill defined, why should we believe we can learn much from such research?

Thanks for raising your voice from the wilderness.
Larry

Truly horrifying.

As usual in our era, these authors have wildly inappropriate faith in research data. In this case the data points and categories are phenomenally limited and warrant no conclusions whatsoever.

You would need at least 500-1,000 different individualizing characteristics, including biometrics, genetics, psychological attributes, birth order, geographical location, etc. to draw valid conclusions that apply to specific individuals.

Instead, the authors used overly broad categories which contain enormous heterogeneity such as sex, race, socio-economic status, etc.

Human beings come in an hugely varied assortment, which is not remotely described by a few broad categories such as sex, race, socioeconomic status.

Sure, there are all sorts of patterns if you look at data through the lens of these categories. But this tells you nothing, absolutely nothing, about any given individual within the group.

The authors' recommendations will therefore help some, not affect others, and harm yet others.

Be warned all of you who blindly believe research findings - the state of research methodology throughout science and medicine is woefully inadequate and often causes major harm.

The question any parent has is 'what is best for MY child?' This question is not answered by this research and will not be answered until we develop a more sophisticated and manner of performing studies - one that takes into consideration our biochemical and genetic individuality.

The excessive returns to a consolidating finance sector are weakening the rest of the U.S. economy. Finance is best the supporting player to the production of goods and services. Now that the production of tangible goods and services has been subsumed to the needs of financial markets, we are shutting off the engine of economic growth.

What a waste. What a tragedy.

I have no research on which to base this, but as a parent with two high-performing middle school-age children, it is obvious to me that the more academically successful kids are the ones whose parents care enough to make sure they are in school on time, every day, with their home work completed. If parents are committed to their children's academic success and involve themselves in whatever their children need to be successful , whether it be providing a home environment conducive to learning - including limiting TV and internet - or dialoging with their teachers if their kids are having difficulty, their children will do much better in school than those with parents who are not similarly "involved". Schools can only do so much without parental support.

Um, the whole point is that firms with a three millisecond advantage were front-running so efficiently that one of them made profits 1,237 days in a row.  Since the odds of making an honest profit on any given day really shouldn't be much more than 50-50, the three milliseconds make a difference.

Ann,

The problem starts with the belief by professional educators that only a college degree offers any chance of success in life. That is how they found employment so it must be the best way.

What would you have the Justice system do, when the education system failed most of the same people first?

We could release them when they become of age and rearrest them within a few weeks or months. That may sooth the Liberal conscience, though it is hard on those robbed, raped,or murdered by the 7 out of 10 that will find their way back into the adult system in the first year

There are not enough opportunities for the honest citizens how do we find honest employment for released criminals? Especially when that is not what most of them want in the first place?

Despite progress in so many spheres -- now-a-days we have so much less time and patience to look into the heads and hearts and lives of our young people. Punishment in many states is easier than understanding; teaching kids once again that they don't matter. Seems to me locking them up as adults takes their own-life-alienating decisions and just compoundes the original crimes further.

@Joe Brunner.  I think you miss Nigel's point.  While we are all grateful that you spend the money you make shuffling money around, we really can ask how that is good for the society as a whole. You mention in very positive terms the two most destructive and/or useless things in our society -- the stock market and the defense industry.  If this is all a society has to offer then pretty soon the people in the finance sector are going to need the defense industry to protect all the stuff they have accumulated in their endless search for More. More anything as long as it is more.
Joe, You are right. But at one time there were other industries besides finance where you could make a living.

@Joe:
The financial trading industry creates jobs to trade finance more quickly using information technology.

The problem is, those are jobs to support an industry that doesn't ad value unless they facilitate the creation of real jobs, in real industries, with real numbers of people and products and that have export potential.

We need finance to facilitate the proliferation of socially constructive enterprises that build real things for real markets. All that activity to support financial trading just for the sake of financial trading is no good if it doesn't contribute to the economy outside of trading which is much bigger.

And the point of the column, is it really isn't doing that. While other countries build better or new sectors of industry we are simply enlarging our financial sector at the expense of all other sectors.

If you can't see the problem in this, then maybe you suffer some myopia, but let me remind you of this saying Ross Perot once mentioned: as a nation, we can't be a great powerful and prosperous nation by not making things... "We can't just sell each other life insurance"

The focus has to be else where, where it is more socially constructive to a better healthier less dysfunctional economy.

More broadly, does speculation, in the form of fast-turnover trading (say, holding an asset for a week or less) help the economy? I can't see any way that it can. True investment, that benefits someone other than just the investor, requires a long time frame, say a year.

Yes Merete, that is why I who am in a sense the opposite of you but with the common experience of being a volunteer working with children trying to learn write often in the Times something like:

If you (society) are going to intervene, you have to intervene early.

This case has been made in the discussion of the de Blasio proposal for providing universal pre-school.

It begins earlier, pre,peri, and post natally and. You, Adler, and Love (commenters) all understand that.

More power to you.

My children grew up in a primarily white, suburban neighborhood in CA.  Having grown up in Europe myself, it was strange to find that, as a volunteer in their school, I found situations that I was not prepared for and didn't handle well.  Children were bussed in from other areas of the city, and they were hugely resentful and difficult, but their parents seemed equally concerned and involved.  Our problems start much earlier than any school.  The social strata, history and policy in the US will set some children back for generations to come, especially in certain states.  These states will drag down our statistics, and they do not seem interested in looking at their problems constructively on the state level.
